hints.content: Let's look how Kim and Jo represent the image.

###Kim's way

Kim says the image represents $4\times7$, or $4$ groups of $7$.

[[☃ image 1]]



The array shows $\blueD4$ groups of $\purpleC7$ or $\blueD4\times\purpleC7$.

So, Kim is correct.

options.alt: An array of 28 dots arranged in 4 rows of 7 dots each. A line separates each row. Along the left side of the array, the rows are numbered 1 to 4. Along the top of the array, the columns are numbered 1 to 7. !

hints.content:
##Jo's way

Jo says the image represents $7\times4$, or $7$ groups of $4$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can group the array into $\purpleC{7}$ columns with $\blueD{4}$ dots each, or $\purpleC7$ groups of $\blueD4$.

The expression $\purpleC{7} \times \blueD{4}$ also represents the array.

So, Jo is correct.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Yes! In a rectangular array, the $\blueD{\text{number of rows}}$ is always the same as the $\blueD{\text{size of the columns}}$. The $\purpleC{\text{number of columns}}$ is always the same as the $\purpleC{\text{size of the rows}}$.

In multiplication, we can switch the factors without changing our total.

$\begin{align}
\blueD{\text{ Number of rows}}\times\purpleC{\text{ size of the rows}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}\\\\
\purpleC{\text{Number of columns}}\times\blueD{\text{ size of columns}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}
\end{align}$

We call that pattern the **commutative property of multiplication**.

options.alt: An array of 28 dots arranged in 7 columns with 4 dots each. A line separates each column. Along the top of the array, the columns are numbered 1 to 7. Along the left side of the array, the rows are numbered 1 to 4. !

hints.content: Both Jo and Kim are correct.
